awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SHF: Medium: Practical and Rigorous Correctness Checking and Correctness Preservation for Irregular Parallel Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important — and in some cases, lifesaving — computations are performed on graph structures consisting of millions of vertices and edges.  For example, such graphs might represent medical information, protein interactions, or taxonomies of diseases.  Since these graphs tend to be large, they are processed in parallel to fully harness the speed offered by modern computers, which use multicore processors and often general-purpose Graphics Processing Units (GPUs). Unfortunately, parallelizing graph computations is difficult, especially for GPUs,and often leads to accidental uncoordinated accesses known as data races.  Data races can be hard to track down as they only sometimes corrupt the result.  The project's novelties are the development of scalable and mathematically sound methods for data-race and other bug detection on graph computations.  The project's main impact is the elimination of many human programming errors to improve the trust in computations carried out on life-critical and other data.

The project develops generic symbolic representations of allowed concurrent operations on primitive data operations.  This provides the
ability to easily boil down new concurrency models into this semantic base to quickly create new analysis tools, thus counteracting verification tool obsolescence.  It augments the power of small-scope symbolic-analysis methods with execution-based dynamic-analysis methods that scale to realistic code and data sizes.  The project derives real-world case studies from high-performance CUDA and OpenMP implementations of important graph algorithms developed over a decade. The project plans to publicly release the new data-race checking tools as well as verification micro-benchmarks and rigorously verified parallel graph codes.  It is also training students whose education is advanced by teaching them modern program analysis methods.

This award is co-funded by the Software & Hardware Foundations Program in the Division of Computer & Computing Foundations, and the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Collaborative Research SHF: Medium—Practical and Rigorous

Correctness Checking and Correctness Preservation for Irregular

Parallel Programs

 

OUTCOMES REPORT

 

NSF 1956106: University of Utah (PI Ganesh Gopalakrishnan)

 

---

 

### 1  Introduction

 

 

When the project began, GPUs were already

indispensable to high‑performance computing (HPC) and machine

learning; today they underpin nearly every scientific breakthrough

from exascale simulations to generative AI.

 

Yet the relentless drive

for performance on massively parallel hardware continues to outpace

the ability of developers to reason about correctness—especially for

irregular algorithms whose dynamic data dependencies thwart simple

synchronization patterns.

 

Our joint objective has been to close that gap by (i) formalizing the

semantics of irregular parallel programs, (ii) building scalable tools

and benchmarks for detecting data races and related bugs, and (iii)

cultivating a community that values rigorous correctness alongside raw

throughput.

 

---

 

### 2  Collaboration Fabric

 

Each PI led a cornerstone theme—formal verification (Siegel), dynamic

analysis and benchmark curation (Burtscher), and heterogeneous‑system

correctness (Gopalakrishnan)—while serving as co‑investigator on the

others’ tasks.  PI Siegel lent formal expertise in CIVL-based rigorous

race checking.

 

We organized work as follows:

 

* Weekly one‑hour teleconferences between Burtscher, Siegel and

  Gopalakrishnan drove design decisions for HiRace and Indigo, plus

  advances in CIVL.  Mentorship deliberately spanned campuses:

 

  - Gopalakrishnan serves on Siegel’s student Alex Wilton’s

    dissertation committee, while Burtscher mentors Utah student

    John Jacobson and contributed key optimizations to Jacobson’s

    race‑checker.

 

This distributed mentoring accelerated research.

 

 

### 3  Community Catalysis

 

The following workshops were organized:

 

1. CoDaC 2024 — Correct Data Compression (Montréal,

22 July 2024). The first workshop dedicated to mathematically sound

lossy compression convened domain scientists, compiler experts, and

mathematicians. All three PIs served on the organizing committee,

chaired sessions, and delivered opening remarks. The program

(bit.ly/correct-data-compression-2024) now serves as a valuable

checkpoint of community wisdom.

 

2. VSS 2025 — Verification for Scientific Software (to be held

May 2025, link above). While the workshop itself falls after the

award, preparatory collaborations already seeded earlier.

 

3. CSC 2023 — DOE/NSF Workshop on Correctness in Scientific

Computing (co‑located with PLDI 2023, Orlando). Siegel and

Gopalakrishnan co‑organized this forerunner. Its final report, now on

arXiv (2312.15640), directly informed a joint DOE + NSF Funding

Opportunity Announcement (CS2, NSF 24‑571) - tangible community impact.

 

### 4  Technical Advances

 

#### 4.1  HiRace: A Scalable GPU Data‑Race Checker

Developed primarily by Utah PhD candidate John Jacobson with

weekly feedback from Burtscher, HiRace pioneers a hybrid approach:

light‑weight compile‑time instrumentation steers a

happens‑before engine that runs on a CPU helper thread, minimizing

GPU perturbation.

 

Evaluated on Indigo, HiRace uncovers 2 times more

racy kernels than prior state‑of‑the‑art iGuard, yet

incurs  less than 18 % runtime overhead. The work was

published in Supercomputing 2024.

 

#### 4.2  GORC: This is a related

Graph‑Neural Race Classification work by PhD student

Anh Tran, mentored by LLNL collaborators and PIs, employed

message‑passing graph neural networks to predict potential races in

shared‑memory OpenMP, CUDA, and POSIX‑thread programs. By training

on Indigo and synthetic kernels, GORC filters candidate locations

before expensive dynamic instrumentation, yielding a significant reduction in

false‑positive volume. This work has been accepted in ISC 2025.

 

#### 4.3  CIVL Model Checker Extensions Delaware’s team expanded their

CIVL verifier.

 

#### 4.4  Indigo Benchmark Suite Indigo, spearheaded by Burtscher’s

student Yiqian Liu and other students at Texas State University

 

#### A complementary development has been Tanmay Tirpankar's CiRE tool which

estimates floating-point rounding errors in LLVM-based representations

of computations.

 

#### Another complementary development has been Xinyi Li's FTTN tool which

finds out key differences between GPU tensor cores through testing.

 

### 5  Student Outcomes

 

* Jacobson is advancing toward his PhD defense (slated for 2025)

 

* Tirpankar is defending his PhD thesis on April 18, 2025.

 

* Xinyi Li defended her PhD in 2024 and is now a postdoc at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL)

 

* Anh Tran is also slated to defend in 2025.

 

* PhD student Al-Mahfoudh has defended a few years ago.

 

---

 

### 6  Looking Ahead

 

Our sustainability plans extend tool lifetimes and safeguard reproducibility.

### 8  Conclusion

 

Irregular parallel programs will only grow in prominence as exascale

and AI continue to intersect. By uniting formal methods, dynamic

analysis, and benchmark‑driven validation, our collaboration delivered

a toolkit—and a community ethos—that makes correctness a design‑time

decision rather than an afterthought.

 

The three PIs thank the National Science Foundation, our respective

universities, and our students whose intellectual curiosity and

persistence transformed grant objectives into tangible and impactful

research assets.
